Posts.Content: hi all, don't know why I'm writing this really, it will be a moan after 6 weeks of scans, biopsies etc I finally had lumpectomy last Tues next day felt quite elated to have got it over with then my partner's Mum died on saturday since then I've felt really low and depressed, as if we've nothing to look forward to for at least the next year both now trying to support each other results appt tomorrow but feel like I just don't care anymore
Posts.Title: Emotions- can anyone relate?

Posts.Content: Thank you so much for your kind replies, and for pointing out the possible anaesthetic connection- seems it's quite a common after effect in some people. I've been on antidepressants for years and usually manage quite well- and have developed excellent faking skills when not so well! tomorrow's appt will hopefully be to find out if they got clear margins and if lymph nodes were clear i already know chemo is on the cards as it's Her2+, hence the knowledge that it's going to take a long time before everything's finished i know everyone dreads that part and I'm no exception anyone know when chemo starts after surgery? all the best on your journeys
Posts.Title: Emotions- can anyone relate?

Posts.Content: Hello I had a lumpectomy and sentinel lymph node removal and like you, wasn't too worried about surgery... It could be just relief that "something is finally happening" instead of all the waiting for tests, results and appointments And probably a bit of denial too, which might be a good thing as it gives you some protection from strong emotions Even now I'm bald and on chemo, I still find it hard to think of myself as a cancer patient! I wish you all the very best Just be aware the anaesthetic after effects might hit you later- about day 9 after surgery I had a very dark day of depression and felt unable to cope, but by the next day was ok again Let us know how you get on x
Posts.Title: Why am I not nervous

Posts.Content: hi everyone, at last it's almost time for something to happen, after the longest month of my life.. i've got Valium 2 mg from GP as I am afraid of a claustrophobic meltdown in the scanning room! Will it be enough, and when should I take it, one hour before? still another 2 weeks til the op.... am full of aches and pains, tired and unable to concentrate, mind running riot thanks for listening, and good luck on your brave journeys x
Posts.Title: MRI tomorrow! Any advice?

Posts.Content: Well done Taralou, they’re all lovely, glad you’re able to be productive- and to give them away too. I’ve just finished a hat and scarf I started about 3 years ago!- the first thing I’ve knitted since the kids were young. Might attempt something else now, it’s very satisfying when you finish isn’t it? I gave my efforts to my daughter as it’s the only hat her toddler son will keep on, although it’s supposed to be adult size he loves it. Also, keeping my hands busy is stopping me shopping online, something I’ve become a bit obsessed with since being off work! Take care x
Posts.Title: My latest knitting

Posts.Content: Hi Lin, I’ve  been meaning to post about Herceptin for a while- having got to 14 out of 18 am really wishing I could stop. Some of the symptoms, apart from the usual streaming eyes/nose, have been nausea, stomach ache, and a strange “going off food” after a few mouthfuls. My whole body aches and I feel heavy and stiff, bloated with swelling all over (rings tight) 18 doses seems an awful lot to me, is it really the norm? Can’t wait to finish. Also find the injection and site very painful at times. Would be great to hear other people’s experiences, and whether anyone has refused the full course. Take care, you’re definitely not alone in this.
Posts.Title: Herceptin, anyone else feel yucky for 4-5 days

Posts.Content: Thanks Boobarama, Yes it does feel strangely liberating.. And everyone knows why you're wearing that hat anyway! Next step- the lint roller X
Posts.Title: I've done it! Shaved my head today...

Posts.Content: Thank you all for your lovely replies, am quite enjoying wearing chemo hats! Some of them are really nice, got 3 with 2 more on order, that should be enough.. Just back from TCH no 2- was there from 8.05 til 16.30, they seemed a bit short staffed and slow to stop the annoying beeps Steak for tea, the weight is piling on..since I stopped working, swimming and going to slimming world have put back about 11 pounds... don't know how to stop it. Still shouldn't complain as cancer cells are being zapped.. All the best on your journeys xxx
Posts.Title: I've done it! Shaved my head today...

Posts.Content: You are braver than me! I'm 64 so will be covering up..sinead o'connor need not worry.. I gave away most of my hair products yesterday- my daughters were on to them before you could say "help yourselves"! x
Posts.Title: I've done it! Shaved my head today...

Posts.Content: My hair stared to fall out on day 13 after first TCH chemo.... About 50/60% came out and looked awful, so have been wearing chemo hats/ beanies. Had to steel myself to go shopping- took several hours to leave the house..fortunately it was raining! My partner and I had discussed when to go to hairdresser, wait for wig to arrive etc..then today I just went upstairs, picked up my basic battery leg shaver and just did it... I thought you needed fancy clippers but it worked perfectly.. Not recommending anyone follows suit- my hair was fine and short anyway, so it may not work for younger/ better endowed women Anyway, pleased I haven't got to do it in public Only trouble is I look like my big brother... Chemo 2 tomorrow All the best to all you brave ladies xxx
Posts.Title: I've done it! Shaved my head today...

Posts.Content: My consultant told me not to use the cold cap as it stops the chemo from reaching the brain. Mine is Her2 positive, which can spread... Having said that, it's hard for chemo to get through the blood/ brain barrier, apparently It may just be his personal opinion but I was happy to go along with it as didn't fancy the sound of it anyway We all seem to get different advice at times..so do what feels right for you Good luck x
Posts.Title: I've done it! Shaved my head today...

Posts.Content: Hi Ranorton and welcome I felt just the same when I found out- it took a while to sink in that chemo would definitely be on the cards, that was the worst bit, otherwise I could've got away with lumpectomy and radiotherapy...But, please don't despair, it seems to have been caught early and the treatment is very effective. My tumour was small but already in lymph node...I turned 64 just before chemo started and have every intention of many more good years. Have now had 2 chemo and come through it ok, yes you will feel the side effects- for me it was like flu/ pregnancy sickness, tiredness, buT that wore off and by day 9/10 things got better... You will be surprised how quickly you come to terms with it, just be gentle on yourself, you've had a huge shock, and everyone on here can relate and will help you through... Wishing you all the very best xxx
Posts.Title: Triple positive - is chemo necessary?

Posts.Content: Thank you Callie Well done on going back to work and getting your hair and figure back! It did dawn on me as I was posting that anyone who has truly put it behind them may not be on here.. My partner thinks it could become a self- fulfilling prophecy if I think it's going to be a struggle...but I just wanted to be prepared for any eventuality Sounds like you've really managed to move on. I'm having Herceptin too, and then bisphosphonates, so it's not really "over" for a while yet But well done, onwards and upwards
Posts.Title: Finishing treatment..

Posts.Content: Thanks everyone for your great replies and sharing your experiences Will definitely pursue the links and keep an eye open for any moving forward courses Well done those who went to work during or soon after treatment- don't know how you did it! Tomorrow is my last radiotherapy, then we're rejoining slimming club which was going so well back in march, to shift the one and a half stone I've put on....having originally lose two and a half- this aspect of treatment is what enrages me the most! Was almost at target and due to go on a fantastic Greek holiday which had to be cancelled, ** ck you cancer! A new thread on recovery/ detox sounds a great idea.. Let's fight this thing and come out stronger and healthier than before Good luck everyone Keep posting how you're getting on Phaedra ( not my real name hahaha but think it sounds strong!)
Posts.Title: Finishing treatment..

Posts.Content: hi everyone I am coming to the end of active treatment- just 3 rads to go Life has been on hold since March, with diagnosis, lumpectomy, chemo, rads and all the usual scans, waiting etc The trouble is, all I keep reading about is the after effects- feeling abandoned, depressed etc! I want to be happy and get fit again, lose weight, grow some hair and put it all behind me, but am getting worried about all these warnings Has anyone just been happy and got on with life afterwards? I don't want cancer to take up any more of my time than it already has- and I definitely don't want to talk about it all the time, let it be gone... Am I being unrealistic Best wishes to you all
Posts.Title: Finishing treatment..

Posts.Content: That's harsh! i didn't see that bit on the pre-op letter til it was too late and I'd been taking cod liver, evening primrose, garlic and a multivitamin right up til day of op i didn't mention it and everything was fine.. obviously i don't recommend going against medical advice, but I'm afraid I just brushed it off as over- cautious could be something to do with blood clotting or thinning hope you don't have long to wait x
Posts.Title: Diagnosed and scared.

Posts.Content: Hi Margaret, Thanks for you reply, that makes me feel better! I’ve never had a bone scan, and at 64 have never broken a bone (touch wood) - the idea is to try to prevent bone mets but my lump was very small so am hoping for the bes t and to cross that bridge if I come to it. And yes, always good to be careful this weather...just waiting for snow to start.
Posts.Title: Anyone refused to take bisphosphonates?

Posts.Content: Hi Everyone, I had an appt today with oncologist and he asked me what I wanted to do about the Bisphosphonates. I said I didn’t like the idea of taking something that interferes with bone formation, and I’m also very prone to heartburn, which it can aggravate. He didn’t push me one way or another, and I found myself refusing them. I just want to get back to “normal” after WLE, chemo, radio and Herceptin...can’t bear the thought of taking more strong meds, and not being able to eat or drink for an hour every morning... He said they would provide about a 3% benefit, which doesn’t seem worth the side effects. Has anyone got experience of these drugs, I would be great to get some opinions, not sure if I’ve done the right thing or not- have read conflicting things about them, thanks.
Posts.Title: Anyone refused to take bisphosphonates?

Posts.Content: Wow, lots of different thoughts and opinions, thanks everyone, I can see some people have good reasons to take these drugs and others are not so sure.. I feel my body’s been through enough already and as I’m starting to feel almost “normal” again don’t want to rock the boat. To anyone still going through treatment, hang in there it does get better..the fatigue has mostly gone, hair growing back thicker, back walking and swimming...chemo was the worst thing I’ve ever had to do, it’s a mental battle too, but we are strong and will fight this thing. Best wishes to you all xxx
Posts.Title: Anyone refused to take bisphosphonates?

Posts.Content: Thank you Think I'm developing a liking for steroids! That make me feel good, and mellow. I don't get the hyped up energy, but I've never been noted for being energetic! Probably a good thing that they only give you the exact amount of tablets...x
Posts.Title: Reduced dose of chemo

Posts.Content: Thank you Goeash & Dreamthief for your encouraging replies. Guess I'm more worried than I realise about all this, though am always laughing and larking about and playing it down to friends and family.. Will just have to trust the medics like everyone else on here All the best and thanks for sharing x
Posts.Title: Reduced dose of chemo

Posts.Content: Thank you for replying I had the reduced dose today, so will have to wait and see how it goes- I usually feel ok til the steroids wear off... The oncologist thought I might "crash" at round 3, and it turns out that my neutrophils had gone down from 3.4 to 1.8... Anyway I'm now glad he reduced it cos I wasn't really living, just existing! All the best x
Posts.Title: Reduced dose of chemo

Posts.Content: Hi everyone I'm having chemo no 3 tomorrow (TCH) and the oncologist had decided to reduce the Docetaxol and Carboplatin by 10% each as I have had more fatigue after round 2. I didn't ask to have it reduced but am happy if it makes life easier. I know logically they wouldn't give an ineffective dose, but I can't help worrying it won't be so good at zapping the cancer My consultant is lovely but has a strong accent and speaks very quickly so I don't always grasp everything he says! The tumour was small but HER 2+ and already in lymph node Does anyone have experience of reduced doses? Many thanks x
Posts.Title: Reduced dose of chemo

Posts.Content: Thanks Bjez, so happy for you that your treatment has done the job! It will be interesting to see what side- effects go away on stopping docetaxel....then I'll know whatever happens is down to Carboplatin/ Herceptin.... I wasn't offered the other drug you mention, is it for pre- menopausal women? Are you planning to go back to work? All the best xxx
Posts.Title: Stopping Docetaxel

Posts.Content: Hi everyone Has anyone had their Docetaxol stopped? I've had 4x rounds of TCH chemo and now oncologist wants to stop the Docetaxol and just continue with Carboplatin and Herceptin  Am pleased in one way as had awful fatigue, nausea and anaemia, plus a sky- high Vit B12 reading of over 2000, which nobody can explain Just never heard of anyone only having Carboplatin and Herceptin  Seems they don't really know what to do with me as the tumour was only 4mm but had already spread to lymph node ( only had one removed) Oncologist was concerned about numb, tingling feet, apparently that can become permanent due to nerve damage I know I should just trust him, but it's hard not to worry Got rads in November, then Herceptin for a further 6 months, then bisphosonates Just want my life back! Love to everyone x
Posts.Title: Stopping Docetaxel

Posts.Content: Thank you for your reply, yes neuropathy is a real concern, so I'm glad he's stopped it, it's a horrible drug and 4 sessions is probably enough. It remains to be seen what the side effects of Carboplatin are, but it should be better having only one infusion.
Posts.Title: Stopping Docetaxel

Posts.Content: Hi Sarah Sorry to hear you're having problems with Docetaxol I had a bad reaction with the first one, but after that they gave me pre Meds and a slower infusion They may reduce the dose, or try another drug I had the drug reduced twice, then stopped after 4 rounds- latest MRI was clear The nurse said reactions are very common, so maybe they need to give it slower, or your onc may decide on something else Hope you get it sorted soon, I'm sure you could do without the worry at the moment On the plus side, the treatment will come to an end eventually- it's 4 weeks today since my last chemo, and I'm feeling reasonably ok, apart from some lingering fatigue All the best, keep us updated x
Posts.Title: Stopping Docetaxel

Posts.Content: Hi Boobylou and congratulations! It must be a great relief. I’m having first year mammogram soon, but a bit apprehensive as breast very tender after radiotherapy, even though it finished in November. Did you find it any more painful than usual? Time to celebrate!
Posts.Title: Good new’s

Posts.Content: Hi Eden Just wanted to say hello and let you know we're thinking of you on your first chemo It is very daunting but I've had 3 now and am a lot less nervous The first one is the most scary, it's the unknown You are brave and strong and will get through it! They will give you med's for any side-effects- probably best to take the anti sickness ones as a precaution, before anything happens! Wishing you all the best x
Posts.Title: *** July 2017 Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Hi Eden Just wanted to say hello and let you know we're thinking of you on your first chemo It is very daunting but I've had 3 now and am a lot less nervous The first one is the most scary, it's the unknown You are brave and strong and will get through it! They will give you med's for any side-effects- probably best to take the anti sickness ones as a precaution, before anything happens! Wishing you all the best x
Posts.Title: *** July 2017 Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: hi all I felt very tired after chemo no2 (TCH) so the oncologist reduced the dose Had chemo 3 yesterday and have just had a call from GP to say my haemoglobin is low. As I eat red meat, dark green veg and lots of fruit, I asked what I more I could do but she said it isn't diet- related and is ordering a different sort of blood test for iron stores, which is apparently separate from the iron circulating in the blood. Just wondering if anyone else has had this, and what treatment they gave you? Many thanks x
Posts.Title: Anyone become anaemic on chemo?

Posts.Content: Thank you for your reply, will have to do some research into this as it's a bit complex isn't it, in fact the human body is a mysterious thing... As least it gives me something else to think about, other than cancer! Hopefully it will be fairly easy to sort out, fed up being tired x
Posts.Title: Anyone become anaemic on chemo?

Posts.Content: Thank you Leolady! I didn’t know the origin of the name, but chose it because it sounds strong- will have to do some research into Greek mythology now. I’ve told anyone who’ll listen that it’s the Herceptin stopping me from losing weight, so now I’ll have to prove it.  Take care and keep posting your upbeat thoughts x
Posts.Title: Last Herceptin...

Posts.Content: Hello everyone, I haven’t posted for a while, but log in frequently to see how everyone’s doing. Yesterday was Herceptin no 18 and am not sure what I should be feeling... Obviously glad about not having any more injections, but can’t rejoice yet as not had Mammogram results, it’s been more than 2 weeks since and haven’t heard anything, in a way I don’t want to find out! It’s been a 15 month roller coaster ride, so to everyone going through it- it does come to an end eventually, so hang on in there. Would be nice to hear other people’s experiences of finishing treatment Love to all xxx
Posts.Title: Last Herceptin...
